<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 291]]<|/det|> **0625/53** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test **May/June 2018** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 322, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 353]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 584, 373]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 393, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 781, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 330, 446]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 504, 461]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 504, 475]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 858, 529]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and 15 minutes on question 4. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 532, 360, 543]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 546, 767, 558]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 605, 583]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 586, 757, 598]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 647, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 854, 836, 863]]<|/det|> This syllabus is approved for use in England, Wales and Northern Ireland as a Cambridge International Level 1/Level 2 Certificate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 876, 735, 888]]<|/det|> This document consists of **10** printed pages and **2** blank pages. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 896, 440, 925]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 898, 590, 925]]<|/det|> CAMBRIDGE International Examinations <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[820, 915, 905, 926]]<|/det|> [Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate how partly covering the surface of the water in a beaker affects the rate at which the water cools.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 576, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 147, 747, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 383, 533, 400]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 425, 883, 600]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 611, 300, 629]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 146, 661]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 643, 918, 675]]<|/det|>
• Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker and cover half of it with lid \(\mathbf{A}\) as shown in Fig. 1.2. This leaves \(50\%\) of the water surface uncovered.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 689, 918, 721]]<|/det|>
• Place the thermometer into the hot water and record, in the first row of Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stopclock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 736, 918, 768]]<|/det|>
• Record, in the table, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(60 \text{s}\), \(90 \text{s}\), \(120 \text{s}\), \(150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 783, 465, 798]]<|/det|>
• Pour the water out of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 812, 920, 829]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 181, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 918, 104]]<|/det|> Repeat **(a)**, using lid **B** instead of lid **A** to cover more of the beaker as shown in Fig. 1.3. This leaves only \(25\%\) of the water surface uncovered. Explain your answer by reference to your results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 670, 181, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 670, 918, 701]]<|/det|> Suggest a change to the **apparatus** that could produce a greater difference between the rates of cooling for lid **A** and lid **B**. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 701, 686, 717]]<|/det|> Explain why the change might produce a greater difference. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 732, 915, 749]]<|/det|> change .................................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 795, 915, 810]]<|/det|> explanation ............................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 840, 920, 858]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 917, 121]]<|/det|>
A student thinks that the cooling rate is directly proportional to the percentage of the surface area uncovered. He wants to draw a graph of cooling rate against the percentage of uncovered area to investigate this.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 917, 167]]<|/det|>
Describe how his graph line will show whether the cooling rate and the percentage of surface area uncovered are directly proportional.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 144, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 243, 695, 260]]<|/det|>
Students in other countries are carrying out the same experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 274, 858, 291]]<|/det|>
Suggest a factor that they should keep the same if they are to obtain similar readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 365, 917, 383]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 780, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the force needed to just slide a block across a surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 917, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how the force needed varies with the mass of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 151, 398, 167]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 181, 675, 198]]<|/det|>
a light, flat wooden block fitted with a hook as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 507, 228]]<|/det|>
a pulley which can be clamped to a bench.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[223, 250, 770, 363]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 411, 324, 427]]<|/det|>
<pre>In your plan, you should:

<pre>• list any additional apparatus needed

<pre>• describe any precautions which should be taken to ensure reliable results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 565, 520, 581]]<|/det|>
